com.guidewire.util
Class Assert

java.lang.Object
  com.guidewire.util.Assert

public class Assert
extends java.lang.Object

Assert class that can maps to JDK1.4 assertions. If possible, use the "assert" keyword instead of calling methods in this class.

check

public static void check(java.lang.String message)
Variant of Assert.check() that throws AssertionError if the message argument is non-null. Use this variant when computing the message is computationally expensive and you want to avoid it in ordinary operation. e.g., 
 Assert.check(someCondition ? null : buildFailureDescription());

Parameters:
message - If null, the assertion succeeds. Otherwise, the assertion fails and message is displayed as the assertion failure message.
Throws:
java.lang.AssertionError - if message is non-null.

check

public static void check(java.lang.Throwable t)
Calls check(String message) with the stack trace of the throwable as the message.

Parameters:
t -

checkException

public static void checkException(java.lang.Class callingClass,
                                  java.lang.String context,
                                  java.lang.RuntimeException re)
                           throws java.lang.RuntimeException
This method will throw an exception if checkException is enabled (done by setting the system property com.guidewire.util.Assert.checkExceptions to true) and either:

  • checkException is enabled for the class callingClass (done by setting the system property callingClass's fully-qualified class name.checkExceptions to true)
  • checkException is enabled for the named context of the class callingClass (done by setting the system property callingClass's fully-qualified class name.checkExceptions.context to true)

This method can be used to test error handling by simulating difficult- to-reproduce error conditions, like database deadlock, out of memory errors, etc.

Parameters:
callingClass - The class defining the context in which this method is called; allows you to turn checkException on or off for an individual class
context - The name of the context within the class, or null; allows you to have several exceptions or groups of exceptions in a single class that can be turned on or off. For example, a database component might have different contexts for retryable failures (deadlock, connection pool failures) and non-retryable failures (duplicate keys, foreign key constraint violations).
re - The runtime exception to throw if checkException is enabled for the given class.
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException

checkException

public static boolean checkException(java.lang.Class callingClass,
                                     java.lang.String context)
This method returns true if checkException is enabled (done by setting the system property com.guidewire.util.Assert.checkExceptions to true) and either:

  • checkException is enabled for the class callingClass (done by setting the system property callingClass's fully-qualified class name.checkExceptions to true)
  • checkException is enabled for the named context of the class callingClass (done by setting the system property callingClass's fully-qualified class name.checkExceptions.context to true)

This method can be used to test error handling by simulating difficult- to-reproduce error conditions, like database deadlock, out of memory errors, etc.

This variant is intended to be used to test checked exception types, where a method on Assert can't throw the exception for you because it would have to be declared in the signature of checkException. For example: 

   if (com.guidewire.util.Assert.checkException(getClass(), "CheckedExceptions"))
     throw new GWCheckedException("Simulated failure");

Parameters:
callingClass - The class defining the context in which this method is called; allows you to turn checkException on or off for an individual class
context - The name of the context within the class, or null; allows you to have several exceptions or groups of exceptions in a single class that can be turned on or off. For example, a database component might have different contexts for retryable failures (deadlock, connection pool failures) and non-retryable failures (duplicate keys, foreign key constraint violations).

enableCheckException

public static void enableCheckException(java.lang.Class callingClass,
                                        boolean enable)
Enables or disables checkException for a class. Note that disabling checkException for a class can still leave checkException enabled for certain contexts in the class.

Parameters:
callingClass - The calling class
enable - Whether to enable or disable checkException

enableCheckException

public static void enableCheckException(java.lang.Class callingClass,
                                        java.lang.String context,
                                        boolean enable)
Enabled or disables checkException for a context in a calling class.

Parameters:
callingClass - The calling class
context - The context in the calling class
enable - Whether to enable or disable checkException
